metadata.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Limited v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated March 10, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajkot, in Adjudication Case No. 67 of 1955.

Industrial dispute between appellant (Associated Cement Companies Limited, Porbandar Cement Works) and respondents (workmen) referred for adjudication to Industrial Tribunal for State of Saurashtra under s.10(1) of Industrial Disputes Act.
Industrial dispute arose in 1949, referred on March 22, 1949, award made on September 13, 1949.
1949 award terminated by appellant, new disputes arose, second reference made, second award on July 24, 1951, continuing earlier award with modifications.
Registration of Kamdar Mandal, Cement Works, Porbandar cancelled on July 2, 1954.
Formation of Cement Kamdar Mandal, registered July 7, 1954 (minority union).
Cement Employees Union registered September 18, 1954 (majority union).
Cement Kamdar Mandal gave notice to appellant's manager on September 23, 1954, purporting to terminate 1949 award after two months.
Cement Kamdar Mandal gave another notice on December 20, 1954, purporting to terminate 1951 award.
Cement Kamdar Mandal presented fresh demands on November 22, 1954, mostly covered by previous awards.
Demands referred to Conciliation Officer, conciliation failed, Saurashtra Government made reference under s.10(1)(c).
Appellant raised preliminary objection that Cement Kamdar Mandal (minority) not authorised to terminate awards under s.19(6), second award still in operation, reference incompetent.
Cement Employees Union (majority) raised disputes, conciliation failed, but Saurashtra Government did not refer.
Cement Employees Union impleaded as respondent No.2, supported demands of Cement Kamdar Mandal.
Tribunal dealt with point assuming Cement Kamdar Mandal is minority union, found against appellant on preliminary objections including s.19(6).

legal_issues.text: Can a registered trade union representing a minority of workmen governed by an award give notice to the other party intimating its intention to terminate the award under s.19(6) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947?

petitioner_arguments.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal (minority union) was not authorised to terminate awards under s.19(6), second award still in operation, reference invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.19(6) Industrial Disputes Act; 'any party bound by the award' requires majority representation

petitioner_arguments.text: Terminating award is serious step, requires party representing majority will; minority termination disturbs smooth working.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Scheme of Act, s.18, policy against minority disturbance

petitioner_arguments.text: Relied on Bombay Govt rule 83 under s.38 consistent with majority requirement.

respondent_arguments.text: Minority union can terminate award under s.19(6); notice valid, reference competent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.19(6); any party bound includes group/union acting collectively, no majority needed

court_reasoning.text: s.18 binds all parties, summoned parties, employer heirs/successors, all workmen employed at date of dispute and subsequent; wide circle.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Award binds beyond parties to dispute.

court_reasoning.text: s.19(3) award operates one year; s.19(6) continues binding until 2 months after notice by any party bound.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice by 'any party bound by the award'.

court_reasoning.text: Literal: even single employee; but industrial dispute under s.2(k) requires collective element, not individual unless sponsored by union/group.
Minority group/union can raise industrial dispute under s.10; logically can terminate award made on such reference.
Majority rule would prejudice employees as unions don't cover majority; hard to terminate awards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trade union movement not covering all/majority yet.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 83 not applicable as not in force; decide on s.19(6) construction alone.

holdings.text: Notice to terminate award under s.19(6) can be given not by individual workman but by group of workmen acting collectively through union or otherwise; no need for majority representation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Limited v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute becomes industrial if taken up by trade union or number of persons.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Newspapers Limited v. The State Industrial Tribunal, U.
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved observations on individual disputes needing union/group support.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute, binding nature of awards, period of operation and termination, reference powers.

outcome.summary: Court upheld Industrial Tribunal's interlocutory judgment rejecting appellant's preliminary objection under s.19(6); minority union's notice valid, reference competent; appeal dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; proceedings set for merits hearing.

key_quotes.text: Can a registered trade union representing a minority of workmen governed by an award give notice to the other party intimating its intention to terminate the award under S. 19(6) of the Industrial Disputes Act?
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise, and it is not necessary that such a group or the union through which it acts should represent the majority of workmen bound by the award.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the holding on s.19(6) interpretation.
